title: Mallers on Adding Bitcoin, Going Public, Storing Wealth
description:
Twenty One Capital CEO and Co-Founder Jack Mallers discusses adding bitcoin ahead of listing plans, going public in 3Q and argues that Bitcoin is the best way to store wealth into the future. He speaks with Tim Stenovec on  'Bloomberg Crypto.'
 (Source: Bloomberg)
content: When's this happening? What's an updated timeline? Um, I am on public file with the press release saying that we had filed arrest for some time ago. We are enjoying the communications with the FCC. We're hopeful of aq3 obviously could spill over into Q4, but we think soon. How about that? Q3 this year could spill into into Q4 this year. Yeah. And if we're doing the math, we're almost done with. Q Yeah, we are. So, yeah, there we go. We're putting it together. So I think we're excited. But ultimately it's about our relationship with the FCC and their ability to get comfortable with the transaction. And we feel confident, but a lot of that's not in our control. So we're working with them diligently and we're excited. When you're working with them. What are you finding as the holdup right now? It's just a it's a complicated and big transaction and we have over 43,000 Bitcoin sitting in escrow. We're doing it with kin or equity partner. So there's some big names, there's a lot of capital. And everyone I mean, listen, our job in with the FCC is making sure that investors in the capital markets know what they need to know about the business and everything is disclosed. So we don't plan on ever taking shortcuts. We won't do everything the right way. And that's really my chair. But we're happy with the speed so far. What have you been doing in the meantime while this crypto has been in escrow, while these bitcoins have been in escrow, have you started to land or you have customers? Right now? Nothing I can disclose on this show. I'll be back whenever I can. I'll tell you all about it. No, we've raised a ton of money. We've brought on SoftBank as a minority but significant partner who will join us on the board. So we have, you know, sovereign capital. We have the largest crypto business in the world, cash flow stablecoins in tether. We've built a tremendous leadership team and as I've talked about on the show, we do plan to launch a business. What I would say to you today is I don't know if we consider ourselves a Bitcoin Treasury company, why not? We have a Bitcoin Treasury business. We go out, we've already raised a convertible bond, very attractive terms to our shareholders. We've been able to acquire Bitcoin in a phenomenal way. So that's our Bitcoin Treasury business. Free to raise capital by Bitcoin creatively. We also are going to build products. We plan to have cash flow. And so as a Bitcoin Treasury company, our our sole purpose is not solely to creatively raise capital to acquire Bitcoin, it's also to contribute to Bitcoin story through technology, through products, have customers have cash flow. And we think that makes us materially different than a lot of the other, you know, maybe dozens of businesses. Who knows their plans. But I want to be concretely clear that we are see ourselves again. Are we competing with a Coinbase? Are we competing with a strategy? And we think, why not both? We're capable of both of those. And so I don't know if I agree with the categorical marketing term of Treasury Company for 21. What would you call yourself then? A Bitcoin company? We want to be the best Bitcoin company in the world. And what does that actually involve? Because if we look at the landscape right now, we can see companies like Coinbase, for example, that are really focused on being a marketplace, being exchange, and then you have the strategies that are focused on the Treasury side of this for you. Where do you see the most area, the biggest area for growth? Oh, you put it right on a T for me. I'm going to hit it out of the park. That's exactly the market hole we want to fill. Is that what's the hole, though. The hole. Those companies are there. Yeah, but the whole is there's a lot of exchanges that aren't focused solely on bitcoin, Bitcoin financial services. We think they're missing the forest for the trees. Bitcoin's a $500 trillion asset in the making. These other technologies and crypto coins are maybe going to replace an Amazon. And so we think the focus on Bitcoin financial services and not getting diluted our focus through all these other speculative vehicles. And then for strategy strategy is the founder of this Bitcoin Treasury idea, which is an incredible business and Michael Saylor has been able to prove that. But they have yet to explore the idea of bolting on an operating company on top of that and using capital markets and their balance sheet to monetize this Bitcoin trend. We think we can live in the intersection of those. With my experience at Strike Tether's experience running Stablecoins and Usdc SoftBank are access to capital there. We think we can do both and blend those worlds into what will be a very unique Bitcoin vehicle in the capital market. How do you know this is a problem that needs to be solved? What evidence do you have that this is a hole that needs to be filled? Because my partners and co-founders made about $5 billion of net profit in Q2, that is tether and they hold Bitcoin on the balance sheet. They support a lot of Bitcoin adjacent businesses like mining, like lending, like brokerage services. And I myself at strike, we just had our largest quarter ever. We're one of the biggest financial services firms in the world when it comes to Bitcoin. So I don't know if two better experts to lead the Bitcoin train in the capital markets than us. So the experience comes with our resume. What's your outlook on the Treasury part of this specifically? Because as we've been covering closely on this program, this is an area that has just exploded over the last couple of quarters. I mean, you have biotech companies going in, becoming crypto treasury companies right now. I'm like Novogratz has said, the idea here might start to fade a little bit. Do you do you agree with that? Well, I'll give you a. An opinion on both sides. One side, you've got the fixed income market that's been 40 years running only up, that's now turning down that markets rolling over the 6040 portfolio as we know it might be dead. Bonds are five straight years of red of losses. And so you need to find ways to capitalize yourself. If it isn't dollars, if it isn't treasuries, if it isn't an index of stocks, Bitcoin and assets like gold are maturing as a neutral reserve asset that you can capitalize yourself on. So I think more and more companies, governments, sovereigns, endowments, individuals will begin to capitalize on bitcoin. Now, to take the other side of is this market frothy? I think it is right. What we've learned is creating a Bitcoin treasury company is not a scarcity within itself. Anybody can register a business attempt to go public and try and raise money to buy Bitcoin. What we believe at 21 again, is the success is going to lie within the ability to attract massive, massive swaths of capital and actually build a business on top of this opportunity that generates cash flow and has customers and is contributing real world market value to the end consumer. That's at least our opinion, and we think that's a far more scarcity than your 20th Treasury car. Last time you were on our program, you gave this idea. It kind of went viral on on after we spoke, but it was this idea of the idea of existing and being paid to exist through cryptocurrency. The idea that, you know, you sitting there at at work all day long, you're not necessarily being compensated for what you're doing. And you see crypto as being a solution to that. I got to be honest with you, I didn't quite get it. Okay, I want you to paint that picture for me and get me on board. Yeah, well, so first of all, I think it's Bitcoin, not crypto, you know that. But just to clarify for the audience, it's it's Bitcoin specific. Well, that's just your view that the Bitcoin is the crypto that you're focused on. Yeah, but I think it's Bitcoin is the money within the crypto sphere. And the point really here is, is this Tim Every single day you make a decision on how to get compensated for your time, your energy, your effort, your labor. I'm watching you. I'm sitting in the in the behind the scenes. I'm watching you haul your butt. You're doing a great job on this show. You need to somehow capture the value you're creating for all of us here, and you need to somehow save that value so that tomorrow you can pay rent, you can get groceries, you can travel home and see your parents. That comes every two weeks in the form of a paycheck to me. Right. But what the number sees the value in that they hired. Correct. So you're going to get a paycheck in the form of dollars. But those dollars are losing value in the things that you need in your life. Anywhere between two and 20% depends on what you want. You want a Caesar salad, 2%, you want a nice house, 20%. And so you need to find a way to persist and save and store that wealth. And you make a decision every single day, whether you know it or not. Unfortunately, because the dollar being debased, everyone is a speculator here filming and watching us. And so you have to make that decision. And in my opinion over the last 15 years, and it will continue to be so Bitcoin is the best place to do that. Take the wealth you're creating today, bring it with you tomorrow.
summary: Mallers, founder Michael Saylor, has stated that they aim to be the best Bitcoin company in the world, aiming to add over 43,000 Bitcoin to the market. The company has raised a significant amount of money and has brought on SoftBank as a significant partner, who will join them on the board. They plan to launch a business and aim to contribute to the Bitcoin story through technology, products, and cash flow. They also aim to build products and have customers have access to cash flow through these products. The firm's focus is on improving the market for Bitcoin financial services, not solely acquiring the currency. They believe they can live in the intersection of these trends and using their capital and balance sheet to monetize this Bitcoin trend.
shortSummary: Q&A CEO Mallers discusses progress on integrating Bitcoin into a Bitcoin Treasury company, going public, and launching products with significant investment funds.
argos_summary: The interview discusses a Bitcoin-focused company that is awaiting FCC approval for a transaction involving 43,000 BTC in escrow and has secured SoftBank as a significant partner. The founders emphasize their dual role as a Bitcoin treasury and marketplace, aiming to blend capital‑market access with Bitcoin financial services. They highlight the growing need for dedicated Bitcoin infrastructure, citing their experience with stablecoins and large financial operations. The company plans to raise capital through convertible bonds, acquire Bitcoin efficiently, and build products that generate cash flow for customers, positioning themselves as a leading Bitcoin vehicle in the capital market.
